Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modern Manufacturing Education- A Collaborative Teaching and Learning Experiment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of the project, which is a collaboration involving Northern Illinois University, Texas A & M University, and North Carolina State University, is to develop course materials in modern manufacturing technologies and establish methodologies for collaborative teaching and learning of these materials. The course materials reflect advanced manufacturing processes recently adopted by industry and state-of-the-art manufacturing technologies and have the potential for significant near-term impact on industry. The course is taught simultaneously at all three universities and the students are collaborating across university boundaries and so the project includes significant efforts in the design and development of collaborative teaching and learning mechanisms. The evaluation, being conducted by an experienced evaluator, is examining the effectiveness of the instructional material and strategies and the effect on student learning. The project team is disseminating through website postings, conference presentations, and journal publications. Broader impacts include the dissemination of the instructional materials and results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to (a) develop lecture materials and laboratory sessions on selected advanced manufacturing topics focusing on advanced manufacturing technologies, research and development trends in manufacturing, and the state-of- the-art manufacturing technologies that can potentially generate significant impact in the near future, (b) develop collaborative teaching and learning mechanisms that will guide the interaction among the instructors and the students across the three participating universities, and (c) assess the influence of collaboration on student learning. The PIs from Northern Illinois University, Texas A & M University, and North Carolina State University collaborated to develop the course materials. A total of 9 modules were developed by the three PIs (including laboratory experiments).

 The compiled data from students’ surveys as well as class performance showed that participation in this course increased students’ knowledge of manufacturing and the students became more aware of the cutting edge research and development in manufacturing. To compete and succeed in the global market economy, students need to acquire effective engineering communication skills. Students were surveyed for their perceived preparedness and confidence in effective communication. The pre- and post-survey data showed a perceived gain from 4.05 to 4.42 in communication skills. Students who participated in collaborative projects with peers from other institutions commented that they were better able to communicate with people without meeting in person.

 Although the students who took this course felt that they had to put more effort to establish meaningful collaboration with team members from other participating schools, the surveys showed that the students significantly valued the collaborative project experience. As the projects were structured to take advantage of manufacturing equipment and other facilities that may only be available from one institution. The projects designed to mimic work environment that require engineering teams to work on a project from different locations helped to prepare the students for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century. Graduating students who were seeking employment commented in the instructor evaluation forms that, this course made them more confident in discussing manufacturing challenges with potential employers during interviews. The findings from this project are now being compiled in a manuscript to be submitted for journal publication.
